Collaborative Research: High Speed Imaging Guided Large Eddy Simulation Model Development for Turbulent Flames

The proposed research effort is to develop computer models for practical flames that are usually embedded in turbulent flows such as those in aircraft engines and power generation plants. The improved modeling tools developed here can be extended for use in many other fields such as soot modeling, fire simulations, geophysical fluid dynamics, and environmental sciences. The principal investigators will furthermore continue their practice of mentoring a diverse group of high-school and undergraduate researchers to attract and prepare them for graduate careers in science and engineering.

A comprehensive understanding of flame stabilization is critical for clean and efficient combustion in future power, propulsion, and transportation systems. In this context, the large eddy simulation (LES) methodology provides a suitable framework for modeling flame stabilization and related combustion dynamics. However, current LES models are far from ideal and introduce simplifications that potentially alter the temporal dynamics in the simulations. Here, the LES modeling approach will be reformulated to introduce temporal statistics and a non-equilibrium dissipation rate. Simultaneously, high-speed imaging data will be combined with very large-scale direct numerical simulations (DNS) to validate central assumptions in the statistical data and LES model. An industry partner will collaborate with the research team to ensure the relevance of models and experimental data. Educational and outreach components will aid the transfer of new knowledge and technologies to the classroom and industry. The intellectual merit of the proposed work lies in providing a comprehensive understanding of flame stabilization beyond typical one-point, ensemble statistical averages and will enable the development of a robust and predictive computational modeling. It will take advantage of recent advances in high-speed laser-based imaging and DNS to expand the range of applicability of the LES modeling approach. The CFD models and experimental data developed here will be made accessible to the gas turbine industry and the well-established international working group on turbulent non-premixed flames (TNF).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the research project was to investigate multi-dimensional, multi-parameter dynamical information from new high-speed laser-based diagnostics techniques to help guide the development of large eddy simulation (LES) combustion models. A key element of this work was to investigate experimentally measurable surrogate quantities that can provide critical information for LES model development and validation. The selection of appropriate surrogate quantities focused on multidimensional and multi-parameter data that can be acquired with sufficient spatiotemporal resolution for comparison with model results at relevant turbulent flame conditions. The development of experimental techniques for improving the accuracy of LES models is critical for predicting the combustion behavior of alternative fuels as well as advanced and hybrid combustion systems for power, propulsion, and transportation systems. 

A key project outcome includes the development of the first four-dimensional (x-y-z-t) volumetric laser-induced fluorescence (VLIF) measurements of key species needed for understanding combusting flows. This includes the first measurements of the volumetric distribution of fuel and combustion intermediates such as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and formaldehyde at rates of 10 kHz or more. The work also demonstrated the first measurements of soot volume fraction using volumetric laser-induced incandescence (VLII) at rates of 10 kHz or more in combusting flows. Finally, measurements of the volumetric distribution of temperature were conducted for the first time using two-line VLIF of the hydroxyl radial (OH).  These studies lay the groundwork for multi-dimensional, multi-parameter measurements for thorough model validation at realistic time scales relevant to combustion devices for energy and propulsion systems. The methods developed in this work were thoroughly characterized using carefully conducted experiments to discern the spatiotemporal resolution and accuracy of the measured parameters.

Another key scientific outcome of the work is the advancement of multiple chemical species that can be used to infer the spatiotemporal distribution of the heat release rate in flames, which is critical for the validation of practical numerical models. By measuring formaldehyde and the hydroxyl radical simultaneously and with high dynamic range, it was possible to track the relative heat release rate and measure the heat release layer thickness in flames at kHz rates for the first time. Measurements were applied to a rapid compression machine that simulate internal combustion engine conditions.

A final technical outcome was the advancement of particle image velocimetry up to 100 kHz rates for high-bandwidth measurements of spatiotemporal scales in turbulent flows for the first time. This also led to the demonstration of three-dimensional velocimetry combined with species measurements using laser-induced fluorescence, as well as high-speed triplet-pulse particle image velocimetry for the first time for improved accuracy, error checking, and acceleration measurements.

This work has been disseminated in 8 archival journal publications thus far, numerous conference papers and presentations, and invited talks at national and international conferences. It has also inspired the use of high-speed velocimetry at facilities such as Sandia National Laboratories for measurements in transonic flows and at the Air Force Research Laboratory for studies of post-detonation fireballs and combustion processes. There is also significant follow-on work in hypersonic flows and applications to engine propulsion systems for improved efficiency and reduced emissions.

Key educational outcomes of this project include the training of a diverse workforce and mentoring of doctoral students who have taken positions in national laboratories and academia. This includes a member of the technical staff at Sandia National Laboratories (formerly at the Air Force Research Laboratory), a tenure-track faculty member at Iowa State University (ISU), and a tenure-track faculty member at the Milwaukee School of Engineering (MSOE). The work has also supported underrepresented minorities via undergraduate research experiences in the principal investigators laboratory, one of whom is now a new member of the PIs research group.
